title: Burglars blocked by barriers? The impact of physical and social barriers on residential burglars' target location choices in China

study_area_description: A major Chinese city with 2643 communities, each with a relatively homogeneous population
data_sources: Municipal Public Security Bureau of ZG city
suoa_description: Communities with a relatively homogeneous population
suoa_justification: Communities are used as they have a relatively homogeneous population and are a common unit in crime location choice studies
sampling_approach: Random sampling for burglaries with multiple offenders
choice_set_definition: All 2643 communities in ZG city were considered as potential targets
main_results: Residential burglars are less likely to target areas requiring crossing physical barriers, especially multiple rivers. Local burglars prefer communities with a majority of local residents, while nonlocal burglars do not show a strong preference for nonlocal majority communities.
significant_predictors: Distance from home, physical barriers (rivers and roads), social barriers (Hukou status), proportion of houses built after 2000, rent price category, proportion of high-rise buildings, number of households.
model_performance: Pseudo-R² = 0.3280 for the full model with both physical and social barriers.

title: Modeling Micro-Level Crime Location Choice: Application of the Discrete Choice Framework to Crime at Places
study_area_description: The area comprises the city of The Hague, several smaller cities including Zoetermeer and Delft, and a number of smaller towns and villages.
data_sources: Police files; Statistics Netherlands
suoa_size: Approximately the size of a football field
suoa_description: Contains on average 18 residential units and 40 residents; nearly always on the same street and not subdivided by physical barriers.
suoa_justification: Matches the scale at which many theories of crime at places are articulated and may appeal to crime prevention practitioners.
model_type: Multinomial logit model; Spatial competition model
sampling_approach: Random sample of alternatives from the choice set
choice_set_definition: Postal code area of the burglary and a random sample of 1,499 out of 23,984 other residential postal code areas
main_results: Proximity and the number of residential properties increase the likelihood of an area being selected for burglary. Spatial competition indicates areas with many nearby residential units are less likely to be targeted.
significant_predictors: Proximity, number of properties, spatial competition factor
scale_effects: Smaller spatial units provide more precise measurement and increased statistical power.
missing_information: Publication year, journal name, DOI, filename not provided
all_variables: Population nonnative; Population ages 15-25; Proximity; Value properties; Number of properties
vars_other: Value properties; Number of properties

title: Relative Difference and Burglary Location: Can Ecological Characteristics of a Burglar's Home Neighborhood Predict Offense Location?
study_area_description: The study focuses on the City of Tampa, Florida, analyzing neighborhood characteristics and their influence on burglary locations.
data_sources: Tampa Police Department; U.S. Census data
suoa_description: The study uses census block groups to minimize within-neighborhood heterogeneity and ensure availability of neighborhood contextual data.
suoa_justification: To account for social and demographic characteristics of neighborhoods that likely influence target selection.
sampling_approach: All arrests for burglaries in Tampa during the study period were included.
choice_set_definition: Each incident has a separate row for each choice alternative among the 334 neighborhoods.
main_results: Neighborhood characteristics, particularly those related to social disorganization, influence burglary target selection beyond geographic distance.
significant_predictors: Concentrated disadvantage, residential stability, ethnic heterogeneity, percentage of Black residents, and distance.
model_performance: BIC and log likelihood values are provided in tables.

data_sources: Police records, Census data

main_results: Burglars prefer residences in neighborhoods with lower residential density, detached residences, single-unit buildings, and renter-occupied residences. They are more likely to target residences in neighborhoods where they previously committed burglaries and residences nearby their home.
